Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Modeling the Invention, Dissemination, and Translation of Scientific Concepts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Scientific advance rests on discovery, dissemination, and translation. And yet, most discoveries fail to get noticed and have practical relevance. Nearly every university, discipline, foundation, government and company would like to know not just how to facilitate the creation of new scientific ideas, but how to get those ideas to spread and relate to practical issues in the world. To address such challenges, this research follows leading philosophers of science who argue that scientific concepts are the basic unit of knowledge, and it is there people observe scientific revolutions and advance. This research identifies scientific concepts using natural language processing techniques. With concepts in hand, it intends to model their interrelation in documents as forming an accumulated knowledge network to which every new publication's conceptual relations can be compared. Through comparison one will identify conceptual discoveries as the arrival of new concepts and conceptual relations. Results from this project will inform a variety of stakeholders concerned with intellectual innovation. The findings will have practical relevance by identifying where and when scholars make creative intellectual contributions, contributions that garner wider attention and reception in fields and domains far afield from academe. It will also identify levers for facilitating more rapid forms of discovery, dissemination and translation. Findings from this research will thus have direct relevance to decisions by academics, government agencies, and non-governmental organizations trying to accelerate scientific advance.

Specifically, this research conducts three interrelated projects that identify the social conditions giving rise to concept discovery, dissemination, and translation. The first study asks what are the conditions that give rise to scientific discoveries like new concepts and new conceptual relations? Here the project identifies ecological conditions, resources, and demographic compositions that enable forms of conceptual creativity. The second study follows concepts over time and seeks to understand how they garner attention. Notably, only some conceptual discoveries actually spread and get repeatedly used. What are the initial conditions surrounding a concept's creation that predicts its entire career? Here, the project intends to study new concepts and new concept linkages, and it will look at their staging (start) and implementation (preceding moment) practices so as to determine what drives the heightened usage of some concepts over others. The third study will follow concepts as they spread beyond their discipline and to domains outside of academia. There the project analyzes how concepts translate across fields, or how they move from basic research applications to applied ones such as those found in patents. It also asks how scientific concepts get archived as accepted knowledge in encyclopedia such as Wikipedia. What leads an idea to go from theory, to applied use, to public acceptance? Again, are there ecological conditions and socio-cultural resources that enable an idea to move across social domains? This research will generate and share unique linked data, and it will create new empirical models and extensions of theory that will shift the way scholars conceive of scientific advance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has resulted in several ambitious papers (all presented at multiple venues). The first paper is being revised and resubmitted to the American Sociological Review. In that paper we use phrase extraction to identify well over 1M token terms in science, of which around 100K are new terms introduced in the last 30 years. We validate these terms by identifying their similar emergence in google books (where similar). We model the uptake of these new ideas in texts over time using multi-level growth models and we apply a theory of cultural, social and institutional resonance to predicting their uptake. We find that the shift to the level of ideas enables us to assess internalist accounts of ideational development - in particular, how semantic conditions and an idea's positioning in the intellectual space of ideas - as distinctive, consistent, and associative - all enable the idea to blossom and find reception, and over and above from social (social networks of support) and institutional conditions (status and positioning of schools and outlets). This is being revised now and should be resubmitted mid-December (Cheng et al).

We wrote a second paper that came out in EMNLP and received some social media attention. That paper concerned the transfer of academic ideas into patents and clinical trials. We ask in this paper whether we can predict a scientific idea will find uptake in applied domains. We use a variety of similar approaches to the aforementioned paper, but here, the outcome is uptake of a scientific idea in another applied domain and as such far less common and voluminous than uptake within science itself. When modeling this transfer, we find that popular scientific ideas spill over into applied domains, but that locating ideas in teams of scholars who also patent; in journals that relate to patents; in fields that bridge, etc -- various bridging locations greatly increase chances of transfer. In addition, and importantly, we find that ideas require a particular semantic context or use in which to be transferred. In particular, an idea needs to adopt a similar neighborhood of related terms to related terms in the applied domains. In other words, scientific ideas transfer when they can be understood at least partly in the same way as ideas are understood in the patent or clinical trial domain. The more the idea adopts intermediary links and gets closer situated to the semantic context of applied ideas, the more it will transfer. In short, we find an idea needs to be interpretable or put into relation with interpretable terms and senses of those terms for applied domains to take them up at great rates. Last, we used machine learning to predict whether a scientific idea will transfer and our model achieves an 85% accuracy rate (Cao et al 2020).

We wrote a third paper that was published in PNAS and received a great deal of attention. That paper concerned the diversity innovation paradox. In the paper, we model how concepts are used in pairs within papers. We identify new pair relations as novelties, and we identify pairs that are subsequently taken up as innovations. Next, we test whether underrepresented groups are more likely to discover and posit new idea-relations, and whether those relations are taken up or not in science going forward. We find a diversity innovation paradox -- underrepresented persons are more likely to identify novel finds than majority group members, but those novel finds are either taken up at a lower rate or the same innovations have less value in securing them tenured jobs in comparison to the same contributions made by dominant group members. In this manner, we took the conceptual innovation work and extended it to ideas about recombination and diversity, and we found a stark inequality science needs to work harder to rectify (Hofstra et al 2020). 

Other papers are underway, but the novelty of the approach and methods, as well as the size of the data, has taken us time and great deal more effort than anticipated. We are making nice progress, but the best work is yet to come. 

Cao, Hancheng, Mengjie Cheng, Zhepeng Cen, Daniel A. McFarland, Xiang Ren. 2020. “Will This Idea Spread Beyond Academia? Understanding Knowledge Transfer of Scientific Concepts across Text Corpora.” Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing (EMNLP 2020).

Cheng, Menjie, Sanne Smith, Xiang Ren, Hancheng Cao, Daniel A. McFarland. “Conceptual Hype in Science.” R&R at American Sociological Review.

Hofstra, Bas, Vivek V. Kulkarni, Sebastian Munoz-Najar Galvez, Bryan He, Dan Jurafsky, and Daniel A. McFarland. 2020. "The Diversity–Innovation Paradox in Science." Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 117, no. 17 (2020): 9284-9291.  www.pnas.org/cgi/doi/10.1073/pnas.1915378117
